feed.title: Demi Lovato Says She Still Struggles With Bulimia, Cutting
feed.subtitle: "I cannot tell you that I have not thrown up since treatment," Lovato said in an MTV special. "I cannot tell you that I have not cut myself since treatment. I'm not perfect. This is a daily battle that I will face the rest of my life."

link.title: Demi Lovato Enters Treatment for 'Emotional and Physical Issues'

content.div:
Demi Lovato has the phrase "stay strong" tattooed on her wrist, and on an MTV special that aired last night, she admitted that she's struggling to do just that.

The 19-year-old "Skyscraper" songstress revealed that she hasn't completely conquered her battles with bulimia and cutting since seeking treatment in 2010.

Taped in front of a live studio audience, the MTV special, which was hosted by SuChin Pak, featured Lovato candidly discussing her issues, including depression, which she said began when her parents split when she was 7.

"I cannot tell you that I have not thrown up since treatment," Lovato told Pak. "I cannot tell you that I have not cut myself since treatment. I'm not perfect. This is a daily battle that I will face the rest of my life."

Lovato also admitted that she was constantly on the phone with her sponsor last Thanksgiving so that she wouldn't throw up her meal. She said she made it through the holiday, but felt guilty the next day.

"An addiction is an obsession, something that takes over your mind and your every thought. You think that you can't live without it. For me, it was not eating and purging and self-harming."

In the doc, Lovato is shown visiting patients at the Timberline Knolls rehab facility, where she spent three months getting treatment for emotional and physical issues.

Lovato, who rose to fame on Disney projects like Camp Rock and Sonny with a Chance, said early success exacerbated her issues. "Everyone kind of made me a role model, and I hated that. I was partying, I was self-medicating. I was always stressing out. I felt like I was living a lie. I felt guilt and shame. I decided to take it out on myself. I harmed myself. It was my way of taking my own shame and my own guilt out on myself, and I was just depressed."

The doc also featured behind-the-scenes footage of Lovato readying her first tour since 2010, when she halted her trek with the Jonas Brothers to enter rehab.

The singer said she finds comfort in her music and her fans (who call themselves Lovatics).

"Every time someone asks me for a picture or an autograph, even if I'm having a bad day and I'm in a bad mood, I remember, 'You're nothing without this person,'" she said. "They make it special."

jenm@dose.ca
